Okay, the war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war. Before invading Iraq, I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the 9/11 terrorist attacks when in reality there wasn't much of a connection between the two. However, the government made it seem like there was a connection and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the 9/11 terrorist attacks and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003. Um, I'm against war, especially a preemptive strike, I was against that. And I think the war in Iraq is kind of a repeat of the Vietnam War in many ways. The government should have learned from past mistakes that they made with the Vietnam War. I mean, a tremendous amount of American soldiers have died and that's horrible. What they were doing was removing the countries government and I really don't think the government was prepared for the aftermath and the void of power and the chaos that was going to occur. Um, and the government and so the United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, which is kind of a similar thing they were trying to do in Vietnam. They were trying to push out Communists and uphold or implement democracy. And I think that the government, the US government should have known that it was going to be a long and hard ordeal that probably wasn't going to be a clear victory like it wasn't a clear victory in Vietnam because no matter how many people may have supported the invasion or no matter how many Iraqis may have wanted the US to come in there's going to be a large number of insurgents and it's hard to put them down when you're not fighting an actual army. You're fighting the citizens of the country. So I think that the government, the US government should have planned for all possible outcomes. I think the government was not as prepared as it should have been, I mean, they didn't really plan for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government. I mean, we're still there today, almost the end of 2006 and we're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and Iraqi police forces to be able to police their own country and it's a long process. And I just think that the US government in a way tried to deceive the American people in making them think it would be a short successful stay in Iraq. I mean, we shouldn't be naive in thinking that because it takes a number of years to implement a new form of government and to have it become successful. I mean, in our own country, democracy was a long struggle and to be able to get to the powerful government we are today was a long struggle and there was lots of tension and there was civil war. Um, it's just not an easy thing to do and I think the government, the US government made it seem like it was a relatively easy thing to do. And so, the war in Iraq, well, that's a difficult decision to make because once you go in there and we've been in there for so long, how can we abandon these people? I mean, we're the ones that took away their government and their way of life so how can we abandon them now? So, it's probably something that we should try to see to its finish but again, there's also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties and how much is too much to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq. I mean, going back to the whole reason for invading Iraq, I mean, if we're invading Iraq and making it a democratic nation, why is it just Iraq? Why aren't we doing this to all these other countries? So, I don't think the US government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions. Let's see, um, I just hope that it ends soon and there will be peace there soon but probably not.

I think there is still sexism in the United States. It's not just about women; I think it's about the specific field of work you're in. I believe women face more difficulties in certain fields because, even with the theory of equality, many people still have a hard time accepting female leaders. This is because society has had a preconceived notion for a long time. Therefore, women often find themselves qualified for a job, but are rejected, because people think women shouldn't be in high positions. Similarly, men face similar challenges in certain fields, such as fashion and childcare. Usually, the parent is the woman, and the man is expected to be the breadwinner. If a man chooses to stay home and care for the children, society looks down on them: "You should be the one earning money for the family." This puts a lot of pressure on them, as they may have originally wanted to be the primary caregivers, while their wives have better jobs. And in the fashion industry, people will doubt a man's authenticity: "You're not a true fashion enthusiast; your style doesn't fit the industry standards." People question his professionalism, worrying he can't understand women's needs. This also relates to geographical background, because some people may have regional cultural biases against women or men. To change this, we need to gradually promote understanding and acceptance of different groups. We need to avoid forced promotion and instead showcase their strengths and abilities. If we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. So, we need to gradually push for this change, allowing people to slowly accept it. We've made great progress, and change takes time. Actually, besides sexism, geographical background can also lead to other forms of discrimination.

I think there is still sexism in the United States. It's not just about women; I think it's about the specific field of work you're in. I believe women face more difficulties in certain fields because, even with the theory of equality, many people still have a hard time accepting female leaders. This is because society has had a preconceived notion for a long time. Therefore, women often find themselves qualified for a job, but are rejected, because people think women shouldn't be in high positions. Similarly, men face similar challenges in certain fields, such as fashion and childcare. Usually, the parent is the woman, and the man is expected to be the breadwinner. If a man chooses to stay home and care for the children, society looks down on them: "You should be the one earning money for the family." This puts a lot of pressure on them, as they may have originally wanted to be the primary caregivers, while their wives have better jobs. And in the fashion industry, people will doubt a man's authenticity: "You're not a true fashion enthusiast; your style doesn't fit the industry standards." People question his professionalism, worrying he can't understand women's needs. This also relates to geographical background, because some people may have regional cultural biases against women or men. To change this, we need to gradually promote understanding and acceptance of different groups. We need to avoid forced promotion and instead showcase their strengths and abilities. If we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. So, we need to gradually push for this change, allowing people to slowly accept it. We've made great progress, and change takes time. Actually, besides sexism, geographical background can also lead to other forms of discrimination.

I think there is still sexism in the United States. It's not just about women; I think it's about the specific field of work you're in. I believe women face more difficulties in certain fields because, even with the theory of equality, many people still have a hard time accepting female leaders. This is because society has had a preconceived notion for a long time. Therefore, women often find themselves qualified for a job, but are rejected, because people think women shouldn't be in high positions. Similarly, men face similar challenges in certain fields, such as fashion and childcare. Usually, the parent is the woman, and the man is expected to be the breadwinner. If a man chooses to stay home and care for the children, society looks down on them: "You should be the one earning money for the family." This puts a lot of pressure on them, as they may have originally wanted to be the primary caregivers, while their wives have better jobs. And in the fashion industry, people will doubt a man's authenticity: "You're not a true fashion enthusiast; your style doesn't fit the industry standards." People question his professionalism, worrying he can't understand women's needs. This also relates to geographical background, because some people may have regional cultural biases against women or men. To change this, we need to gradually promote understanding and acceptance of different groups. We need to avoid forced promotion and instead showcase their strengths and abilities. If we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. So, we need to gradually push for this change, allowing people to slowly accept it. We've made great progress, and change takes time. Actually, besides sexism, geographical background can also lead to other forms of discrimination.
